stream_context.summary: Kaze focuses on engine optimisation, a new animated Star-Select screen, and prototyping an oil-wave hazard with proper death-/respawn logic. He achieves a 5 % render-time gain, fixes culling, and collaborates live with Biobak on graphics alignment.

development_findings.summary: Fixed Mario 64’s original culling maths (45° vs 60° FOV) and moved culling + shadow checks from geo-layout to object struct, saving ~600 µs per frame (≈5 % render-time, 44→46 FPS).
development_findings.quote: I reduced render time by like 5 %. I put the culling into the object itself … that saved like 600 microseconds.

development_findings.summary: New engine interface lets every object easily receive shadows and per-object culling radii; only coins use it now, enemies will follow.
Project is ~70 % complete; 4½ courses still missing.
development_findings.quote: We’re missing like four and a half courses so we’re like over 70 % done at this point.

development_findings.summary: Designed a 60 FPS Star-Select screen: infinite scrolling background tiles, separate render function per star icon for flexibility, custom kerning to truly centre text.
development_findings.quote: Maybe, instead of one geo-layout per thing, we’ll have one render function per thing and the render function decides the geo-layout. That allows the most flexibility.

development_findings.summary: Resolved seam and pop-in issues on star menu by adjusting scroll speed and tile count; implemented better kerning for true centring.
Prototype ‘oil wave’ hazard: player falls in, takes damage, camera holds position, screen fades, Mario respawns at last safe triangle.
Used ChatGPT to generate edge-distance algorithm for safe-triangle detection, drastically cutting development time.
development_findings.quote: You guys have no idea how hard that would have been to program by myself — and this is why I like ChatGPT.

development_findings.summary: Planned ‘decal Mario’ overlay object to render temporary effects (e.g., oil stains) without duplicating base model geometry.
Considering rendering Super Mario Sunshine geometry at 30 FPS on N64 with aggressive F3DEX3 optimisation and PVS.
development_findings.quote: I’m pretty sure we could render Delfino Plaza at 30 … maybe not all of it at once, but it would be playable.

context_findings.summary: Kaze accidentally scheduled two Shorts the same day as a main-channel upload and worries about reduced views.
He insists on single-button, simple controls to keep the game feeling like a game, not a tool.
context_findings.quote: I want to stick to the one-button one-output philosophy.

context_findings.summary: Strong opinion against Unreal Blueprints for core code (“spaghetti”), advocates C++.
context_findings.quote: Programming in Blueprints … you’ll just make a spaghetti salad that no one can read.

context_findings.summary: Appreciates ChatGPT as a productivity boost, openly uses it on stream.
Humorous but pointed reflection on ignoring haters for personal safety (“people can murder you”).

biobak.summary: Provides new Star-Select graphics (scrolling sky, icons), tweaks materials/combiner, and coaches Kaze on Blender array/smoothing nodes.
Requests enemies receive shadows and helps diagnose lighting inconsistencies between Blender and in-game.

key_stories.title: A 5 % Performance Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: While profiling, Kaze realises SM64 culling assumed a 45° FOV and compensated with a hard-coded offset. By correcting the maths and relocating culling & shadow checks into the object struct, he gains ~600 µs per frame (≈5 %).
key_stories.challenge: Render time plateaued around 44 FPS; engine needed optimisation.
key_stories.process: Investigated culling formula, rewrote code, moved logic, benchmarked.
key_stories.outcome: Engine now runs at 46 FPS, and future shadow support is simpler.
key_stories.key_quote: Mario 64 was culling as if FOV was 45°. They just multiplied it with a random number and added 100.

key_stories.title: Re-inventing the Star-Select Screen
key_stories.summary: Kaze and Biobak scrap the ‘boring’ vanilla star menu, designing a 60 FPS version with a scrolling sky, kerning-fixed text, and flexible per-star animations.
key_stories.challenge: Original menu looked static and was hard-coded.
key_stories.process: Biobak supplies new art; Kaze tests tile counts, array modifiers, kerning maths, and scroll speed until seams and centring are solved.
key_stories.outcome: Visually striking, high-performance menu is integrated; more variants incoming.
key_stories.key_quote: This will be a 60 FPS screen easily.

key_stories.title: Safe Respawn in the Oil Wave
key_stories.summary: To make falling into oil fair, Kaze devises a system that records the last ‘safe’ triangle Mario stood on and respawns him there, avoiding edges.
key_stories.challenge: Naïve respawn could place Mario inside walls or over pits.
key_stories.process: Brainstorms with chat, calls ChatGPT for edge-distance maths, implements and tests until camera and velocity behave.
key_stories.outcome: Fade-out death now feels consistent and non-disorienting.
key_stories.key_quote: I invented better kerning … and ChatGPT gave me the triangle code.
